Toyota Production System
An Integrated Approach to Just-in-Time

Authors: Yasuhiro Monden
Reviewer: Datta Dwarampudi

This book talks about the great sucess of Toyoto Production Systems which was developed and promotoed by Toyota Motor Corporation and is being adopted by many Japanese companies in the aftermath of the 1973 oil shock. The main purpose of the system is to eliminate through improvement activities various kinds of waste lying concealed within a company.

Note: All the pictures used on this page are extracted from Toyota Production System, An Integrated Approach to Just-in-Time book. I have written the page numbers in the braces from where these pictures were taken.

Chapter 1: Total Framework of the Toyota Production System

This chapter primarily focuses on various important aspects on which total framework of the toyoto production systems lies on. The topics it highlights are primary purpose, kanban systems, production smoothing, shortening setup time, process layout for shortened lead times and one-piece production, standardization of operations, autonomation, improvement activities, the Goal of TPS.
The author describes about each topic in much detail and in great depth. He talks about how did toyoto achieved its primary goal of profit through cost reduction by employing good strategies like elimination of overproduction, limiting excess inventory and overproduction, reducing unncessary capital investments.
Quantity control, quality assurance, respect for umanity are other important points in the framework of toyoto production systems. To achieve continous flow in the production, Just-in-Time and automation were introduced. Other important systems like kanban systems were introduced to complement the goals of toyoto production systems but kanban systems do not make up the complete framework.
You can visit this link for more information regarding Kanban systesm: Link

Another important point was discussed in this chapter relating to the production of the toyoto production systems. They could eleminate unnecessary inventories and capital investments by employing methods like production smoothing which stated that there should be a production of item when it is able to sell enough in the market or when the market demands that particular product for that day.

Chapter 2 Implementation Steps for the Toyota Production System

This chapter discusses all the important steps regarding a JIT process and also gives a case study about introduction of JIT at Toyo aluminum.
Steps given in the book (on page 25) are:
1. Upper Management Plays a Key Role
2. Establish a Project Team
3. Prepare an Implementation Schedule and Set Goals to Be Achieved within the Schedule
4. Introduce a Pilot Project
5. Move from a Downstream Process to an Upstream Process

The JIT process starts off with the upper management which makes the crucial decisions regarding the production design, plan and allotmenet of resources for the lower employess. This step is followed by establishing a JIT team which overlooks all the processes related to the JIT process, this team consists of sectional and sub-sectional managers. These managers make up plans which needs to be followed by other employees to meed the deadlines then implement the last step to move a downstream process to an upstream process.

This chapter also introduces other important concepts which can be used to implement JIT like 5S concept (Seiri (arrangement), Seiton (tidiness), Seiso (cleaning) , Seiketsu (cleanliness), and Shitsuke (training)), one-piece-production, automation, kanban cards systems.
The other part of this chapter deals about a case study about introduction of JIT at Toyo Aluminum. It talk about how they followed all the steps which are listed above. There campaigns included "JUMP 60" & "GO GO Campaign".

Chapter 3: Adaptable Kanban System Maintains Just-In-Time Production

This chapter discusses about how kanban systems where implemented within Toyota Production System to implement JIT. As previously stated that kanban systems on a whole don't make up the toyoto production systems but kanban systems just complement the JIT. The author defines the pull system as "The subsequent process of withdrawing the parts from the preceding process". The author subsequently explains that final assembly line pulls the necessary products as they know the exact quantity of parts required and then subsequent processes utilize them.

The author talks about various types of kanbans like withdrawal kanban and production-ordering kanban.

The author talks about how a kanban can be implemented effectively in JIT process of a toyoto production systems by stating few rules and talking about why those rules are important for JIT. (These rules are very specific to the toyoto production systems). The rest of the chapter author talks about various kanban systems like express kanban, emergency kanban, job-order kanban, through kanban, common kanban, card or truck as kanban.
